Sunshine. Laura's van rolls down the main drag of a villa The streets are strangely empty. Laura slows. We take in her point of view as she looks into an open do of the village store where a woman reads the paper behind counter. She rolls past a bakery. An old dear wipes off her displa case. We travel on, and past the open door of a pub. Inside, the space is crammed with men silently watching t national football team. Engrossed by a penalty being take As we reach the apex of our passing of the doorway, we he voice announce for a beat “tonight could see this young m become...” the voice is lost, all the faces remain locked Laura refocuses on the road and lets the van gather speed along the empty streets and out of the village into the country lanes.
Laura’s van drives through the lowland.
Laura is driving along the coast road near the Sound of Arisaig. The sun is strong.  28 26. She sees a half visible sign through a bush,'BEACH', and turns.

A sprinkle of vehicles. Laura drives in, scanning out the window she suddenly focuses on something and stops. She parks, then steps out. Leading over the dunes towards the beach is the splatter many footprints. She moves along the path led by the footprints, then sudd breaks off it, drifting away to the right, following one distinct set. The footprints weave off along the dunes eager to find a far away from all the others. She is drawn with them. Far off she can see the main beac and its holiday-makers. 'There', are families and a stretch of sand, laughter and dogs barking. 'Here', is rocky and quiet. Her eyes scan about and find those significant footprints emerge by the shoreline. A LONE MAN in cut-off jeans walks in the breakers. Off to the west, a YOUNG COUPLE sit on a rock. They watch their YOUNG CHILD splash in a shallow pool, th dog leaps in the surf. The low sun sparkles off the water around them. The couple lean closer and become one shape against the ocean. The space between them flashes like a message. Kiss - Sparkle - Kiss Laura focuses on the lone man again. He is pulling his shirt off. He's about thirty, toned. He runs towards the sea. In he goes like a dart. Laura looks at the muscular swimmer as she walks to the beach. The sun plays around her perfect flesh and hair.  27. He swims through the glitter like he's on rails. Laura sits on the sand near his rucksack and boots. He comes back into the shallows. Distant laughter beckons attention along the beach towards the family. Laura follows his gaze. The toddler splashes the dog as it bounds between his roc pool and the tide. The father watches as the dog thrashes into the foam. Giggles and yelps mingle with the waves. The young mother walks into the breakers. She laughs as t undertow shifts her gently. Now the swimmer is walking back towards his things. As he approaches, Laura smiles. He almost stops dead in his tracks but makes it to the rucksack. He pulls out a towel and rolls it around on his head.
You're a good swimmer.
Am I?
You seem good to me... I never learned.
Well, you could still have a paddle.
Is it cold?
Not too bad.
You're not from here.
No, I'm from the Lake District.
On holiday?  28.
No, I'm not on holiday. I'm living up here.
All alone?
Yes.
Do you live near here? He points to a small orange triangle in the distant dunes

I live there, in that tent. The distant tent flutters against the wind. A shout cuts across everything. The young mother's. The swimmer turns his attention from Laura and looks acro to the neighboring bay. Laura follows his gaze. The woman is walking waist deep towards her dog, which is swimming out after its stick. The shout again from the woman to the animal but the drif the stick is enticing it farther out. The swimmer moves away from Laura and back towards the wa edge. Now the dog is in the heavy water. The father calls out t it. The child is still splashing in his rock pool. The mother decides to swim out. It doesn't seem that far the animal. She strokes out, then looks up. She is feeling the deep tug of the powerful undertow and becoming unnerved. The husband edges deeper into the breakers expecting his to turn back. She sets to again but her stroke is erratic. The dog is gone from his thoughts now although yelps sign it's in serious trouble.  29. Sweat breaks on the husband and his eyes fill with alarm his wife goes under for the first time. He plunges in. The mother's face is frozen in realization as the waves s to push at her from all sides. Her open mouth gasps for oxygen and help. No sound. Gulls scream above. The swimmer is now running away from Laura and down the beach. The husband ploughs through the water towards his wife. In another dozen strokes he'll be in with her and in the of the rip tide too. The swimmer is running hard and hits the water like a torpedo. He is moving rapidly towards them. The tide draws her harder and the distance between her an her husband opens up. She goes down for the second time. The husband is pushing after her, his fear drawing his en at every stroke. The wife flails then goes under. Gone. The husband gasps with dread, and feeling the tide pullin around him tries to hasten his stroke. Suddenly the swimmer is at his shoulder. The husband kicks away from him, but his energy is almost spent. The swimmer tries to wrestle for control. Him against the pull, the husband writhing to free himself. The swimmer forces the fight out of him with a clench the flips back, dragging the husband against the current. The swimmer throws exhausted strokes, digging clear of th turbulent water. Stroke clear, kick clear, clear. As his feet touch down, the swimmer drags the man away fr the draw of the tide.  29 30. He battles hard for every step until his legs start to bu with fatigue. With the last of his strength he pushes the man out then collapses into the sand, chest heaving, eyes swimming wit fainting delirium. The exhausted husband stands... and walks back out to sea The swimmer tries to raise himself. Tries to follow. But spent. The husband claws his way deeper out into the swell, mani fuelled by adrenalin. He's carried away by it, flailing like a rag-doll... Then he's gone. Laura is looking. Nothing. No response.

The toddler is standing a few feet from the waves, his li face wet with tears but no sobbing. The swimmer’s body is half out the water. Laura enters frame without urgency and leans over the swimmer. She studies his face as he passes out. She takes hold of him at the belt buckle and heaves him a from the tide. The child, numb with fear, starts to utter half-formed wo manically, over and over.

Daddy go!? Mummy go!? As if unaware of the child's presence, she passes it as s hauls her prize towards the dunes, stopping from time to to get a better grip. The bemused child stays put, watching the jolt of every w with despair and hope. It points out to the horizon, imploring Laura to do something.

Daddy go! Mummy go!'  30 31 31. Laura spots the swimmer’s abandoned rucksack a short dist away. She releases her white-knuckle grip on the body, letting slump, then goes to retrieve the bag. She puts it over her shoulders and tightens the strap acr her body, so as not to interfere with the job at hand. As she takes her bearings again, she sees his body move. elbow is pushing into the sand in an effort to raise his groggy head up. Dead-eyed, she sets off towards him urgently, plucking a large stone from the sand as she goes. She arrives, delivering a single, sharp blow to the back his head. He slumps flat out at her feet. She casually looks about. Finding a path, she is off agai Clearing the dunes she stops, cautious, as the car park looms.
She half-stands, and watches the last vehicles pull away the dusk light. Only her car and a camper van remain.

She opens the passenger door and leans him against the opening. She hauls the body up onto the seat, dragging the legs in place, then fastening him in with the seat-belt. His head flops about. She steadies it with her spare hand as she drives out acr the bumpy car park to the road.

Laura drives. The swimmer wakes suddenly. He looks at her His eyes reach out the window and weave, trying to unders where he is. He presses his head in various places as if trying to pus his awareness back into place. We see him wince under the effort.  32.
We're nearly there.
Nearly where?
My place. He is wet. His bag is on the floor by his feet. These are only certainties.
What's going on?
(mock confused) I'm Laura.
(bewildered) Where is he? Where's the kid?
He’s fine. I knew they should have taken you to hospital. You came to, you said you were alright and you were happy to have me take you.
Is the dad OK? I thought the dad was going to go back in.

No he didn't go back in. You saved him. I've never seen anything like that. So brave. You said I'm going to stop this and you did. You saved that child's father. She looks at him with overt adoration. Like he could have anything he wants.
You're a hero.
I couldn't get the mother.
What you did was a miracle.
What was his name?  32 33.
(Touching the swimmer's leg reassuringly) Do you mean the little boy's name? The hand lingers.

The Bad Man walks along the dunes. He is making for the little orange tent the swimmer had pointed out from a distance. On arrival at the bedraggled tent he dips inside, folds a the worn blanket and pillow, and without breaking rhythm, starts to dismantle the tent poles, pegs and cords. He moves inside and out expertly. Bit by bit it rolls away, creating a tiny bundle that fit under his arm. He stands and looks at the spot. All that is left is a flattened rectangle in the sand. The winds are already blurring the edges of the shape int obscurity. His task complete, he turns back towards the ridge of the dune and the car park it leads to. Thirty feet along the ridge, the Bad Man sees the boy has made his way to the path. The child is standing there in silent desperation, devour by fear. He shivers a little under the Bad Man’s gaze and his eyes roam about as he ponders what crying out actually achieve a situation like this. The Bad Man looks at the child without so much as a blink is covered with a dusting of sand especially around his n and mouth where his tears and slobbers have become caked grit. We can see he’s tried to eat the grass or dirt. His knees and hands are scratched from falling down and h face is weathered from exposure. His clothes are damp from the night in the open air. His reddened eyes are already lost in shock.  33 34. The Bad Man moves on. The toddler tries to follow as he passes by. A dry whimper murmurs at his back as he rouses himself. The Bad Man turns to look at ‘it’ with the sharp focus of scientific instrument. The way a microscope looks at a new germ or a jaded docto studies an X-ray. There is no meaning in his gaze, he is simply measuring equations, examining the possibilities for the most exped action. Satisfied, or rather having understood the probabilities fully, he simply turns away. After a dozen steps, the toddler realizes the Bad Man’s leaving. At first it is like a groan or a deep hum but as the dist between them opens, the power of the sound increases in a astounding way. He now experiences a squeal that reverberates on a cosmic level, a noise of such pitch as to stop the gulls in the to silence the waves. He hears it all the way to the motorbike and even as he k starts the engine the sound still cuts through. Does he drive away in haste? It's hard to say. Perhaps it just us wishing him to flee. Perhaps it would just be mor acceptable if he would, to escape this nerve-jangling how

Laura waits for the traffic lights to turn green. A FAMILY SALOON pulls up alongside. Her attention is sudd disrupted by an incredible noise. She turns as if commanded to look at its cause. There in the back seat is a tiny TODDLER bawling. Its lit cheeks are wet with hot tears and snot. It is obliterating the air with a scream so desperate, as suggest it might at any moment burst. The mother in the car seems calm, not unsympathetic but almost oblivious. Now there is a rasping drawing of breath, a beat, then incredibly the noise goes up a notch.  34 35. The sound echoes the desperation of the child on the beac Laura's eyes are locked on it. The lights change and the saloon pulls away, taking the urgent cries off into the distance. Laura is transfixed for a moment, then she moves to put t van in gear and pulls away, but the lights change to red again before she can. She sits there, her eyes wandering, then drawn to the dis saloon still just visible far along the winding road. An unexpected beat of contemplative stillness ensues. We're seeing a burgeoning. A residue of memory. And the meaning of the event she witnessed connecting wit her. Another CAR comes alongside. Laura sees that the driver, a LAD with a trendy haircut, leaning out the window trying to talk to her. Mates and girlfriends fill the car. Laura winds her window down and thudding music comes into focus.
I thought you was going to ignore me for a minute.
No.
Out dancing tonight?
Not tonight. With that, he jumps the red light, the car bleeding away the night in its version of a burn-off.

Laura drives. A man and woman emerge from bushes. She drives on. Two lads appear in the road. They smile and reach for the van’s wing mirror as she passes.  35 36. She drives on. A swaying bloke walks half in the road. His girlfriend is laughing. He raises his hands jubilantly as Laura passes. She drives on.

Laura sees a FIGURE on the opposite side of the road thum a lift. He is alone except for a kebab which he attends t with gusto. Laura keeps a bead on him as he turns away from the road towards a supermarket car-park. She drifts down the road, scanning, trying to spot him. She stops and gets out. She walks at his pace then slows. She can see headlights and other people moving. A deep beat thuds. Too public, she turns to walk back to van. A white stretch limo has pulled up. A HORDE OF WOMEN pour out. Unsteady on their heels, some stumble with drunken abando They are giggling at anything - a dropped hat is hilariou an exposed breast is gut-aching comedy. Laura is reaching her key into the van door when one of t passing girls approaches her.
Hello love, yee alright there? Laura nods quickly. The girl leans into her.
Yee are gorgeous yee... what yee doing out here all in the dark alone love? Has some cunt upset yee? Laura intimates that she is about to leave.

It's only one o'clock hen, I’m not letting yeh go home yet. I'm not letting yeh. Girls come here, this lass is saying she's away home. Have yee see her? Here love, show the girls...  36 37. She steers Laura towards the crowd of girls. They gather round peering in at her, then they start to chant.
‘Come on out tee night... come on out tee night... looking right tonight... come on out tee night’.
Look at her... she looks like a film star. She waves the girls away but they start to hug her with o familiar zest. It's all good humoured, but there’s a vola energy to it.
Has someone upset yee?
No.

We are taking you intee the party and we are gonna find out who’s upset yee. Laura is swallowed into the happy throng. Gathered up in their flow towards the club entrance. She's almost invisible in this moment, part of the party machine. BIG MEN in black jackets and other figures gather at the doorway of the ‘Deer Park Nightclub’. Lads being drawn out by the high pitched energy of drunk girls on a hen night.

location: DEER PARK NIGHTCLUB. SHORT WHILE LATER. 36

text: One of the girls, a drunk, SLOPPY BLONDE five years past prime, leans in to Laura to be heard above the din of mus
You've got nice ear lobes.
Really?
Very pretty. Nice to nibble. She is close now, her breath hot on Laura's neck.  38. Laura allows her hand to come up and touch her ear lobe.
I've never liked ear nibbling it gives me the jitters. She takes hold of Laura's hand in a strange affectionate controlling grip.
You've got nice lips too.
I’m not the kind of woman who cares to be touched by other women.
Why not?
I’m not really interested in women.
Why not?
I prefer men. They’re predictable. I like to be in control.
Well you can control me.
I find it easier to control men. She puts the squeeze on, gripping Laura’s hand like she’s hanging on for dear life.

You think you’re better than me? The atmosphere is made tense by her sudden dislike. Laura deals with it by looking into her eyes, and meeting tense grip with a smile. SLOPPY BLONDE (CONT’D) I’m a smart woman you know. I’m not being funny but there aren’t many smart women about. I’m a smart one, yeah, I’m not here to be mugged off. (Beat) Where you from?
Do you know London?  39.
Yes, I know London. Who are you?
I'm Laura. We met a minute ago.

(drunk certain) You're not from London. Something off about you. You’re a wrong’un. She throws down Laura's hand. Laura is swallowed up by th sudden, collective mass of dancing bodies. Party people shoulder to shoulder. The drunken girls are going wild. Lights strobe, music booms. Laura is at the centre of the action. A lean LITTLE MAN is dancing close to get her attention. moves come thick and fast. The girls notice. The fat girl leans in between the littl man and Laura.

Throw him back, he’s a tiddler! The little man looks offended, but he styles it out tryin show his worth with an uncertain smile. There is a building energy as she turns away and looks in the crowd. The embarrassed little man moonwalks away. Men are staring at her from all directions. Some openly, furtive. ANOTHER BLOKE starts to dance in front of her. He smiles into her the whole time. Other men hover, their eyes locked on her. People are talking to her. Lads laugh at nothing, hoping she’ll join in. She does. A COUPLE starts snogging nearby. The man overtly looking Laura as he forces his tongue hard into his girl’s head. The dancing and music build.  37 40. The girls are all going wild, spinning like dervishes and braying like donkeys. A spotlight finds them.

(over the P.A.) Holy Moly!! The girls laugh, flattered by the attention. Laura ducks instantly and flees. From above, we see her squeeze away through the endless frenzy of bodies. She tries another direction. We shift with her. She turns again, looking for a different path. Then a strobe light kicks in. A disorienting pulse of lig and dark. Flash frames of outline, then form, outline-for She looks about her, gauging a route off the dance floor. Sudden, hissing blasts from smoke machines belch clouds o white fog. Everything is engulfed now - no warning - distance and intimacy are as one. Hands loom touching her, turning her. Faces leer inches from hers, bodies bump and grind in whiteout. The lights flutter fusing the whirl of limbs and sound in psycho-fairground ride. Everything is flipped and twisted and she's lost in it. Consternation. Overload. Her head is swirling like something’s going to fuse. Her warning lights are flashing red. Out! She needs to get out!

location: DEER PARK NIGHTCLUB. RED CORRIDOR. MOMENTS LATER. 37

text: Laura moves anxiously along a curved red corridor. Looks back to check the wild girls aren’t following. Walking wounded litter the long corridor.  38 39 4l. A girl overcome with booze, legs splayed out. An underage gagging air into the floor. On the curving red wall, she sees an ‘EXIT’ sign. She quickens in its direction. Things quieten as she walks deeper into its long red plus ness. She stops. Another ‘EXIT’ sign points back in the directi she came from. She turns back on herself. She sees a door open up ahead. A girl emerges. Laura head for that door.

Entering, she is confronted by a line of ten identical do She turns to see a mirror wall reflecting the same line o doors. She freezes. She’s lost her bearings. Then the door flings open and a YOUNG MAN walks in. It's bloke she followed into the car park. He looks at her, then smiles nervously.

I don't usually walk into the ladies. But there's a line of blokes out there waiting chat you up. (Shrugs his shoulders) No alternative. (Beat) My name’s Andrew. And in that moment everything shifts back into alignment her. She’s in control again. Of where she is. And how she got here.

Laura is on the dance floor, moving, tempting. Andrew is dancing next to her, smiling his head off. She smiles back.  40 4l 42. He sees his moment and moves even closer. She turns spinn on the shining floor. He leans into her ear.
I was on my way home. (Beat) I’m pleased I came back. Laura leans into his ear.
I can't be seen leaving with you.
No problem. He kisses her neck. Laura gives him a cautious smile. He smiles back and winks as he boogies on.

Laura is on the black floor. Still dancing. No music now. Just the sound of her and Andrew’s dancing feet. She turns, showing flesh. Andrew's slipping deeper into the floor with each movemen He’s unaware of anything but her as he sinks into the blackness. She smiles. He is just a head looking up at her, adoringly. She turns away as he slips under. The floor becomes solid again. She walks back over the spot he went through. Picks up he skirt and walks away. INT. BLACK VOID. UNDER THE FLOOR. CONTINUOUS. 4l Andrew is looking up at the spot where Laura would be if could see through the blackness around him. His eyes adju He realizes he’s looking at the other side of the floor. he’s beneath it. Laura’s footsteps click... click overhead, diminishing. He looks behind him to see the steps ascending into the underside of the floor.  43. He feels for the spot he came in through, but it’s gone. He looks down at his feet. His toes slow slide along the lip of the step. He tries to shift his weight, but his feet can’t make contact. He is weightless, as though underwater. As he desperately tries to regain a footing, he drifts further away. Or the stairs drift. He can’t tell which. Everywhere is blackness. Only the stairs hold any affirma of reality. But there they go. Moving gently away into the dimming vo until the last suggestion of them is gone. He hangs in this amniotic space deserted by everything he understands. Suddenly the far-off darkness shifts. Something is out there. Indistinct. But big and heavy. A barely recognizable FORM drifting in the abyss. A mass of deformed flesh. Bellies balloon around it like a ghoulish Marilyn Monroe skirt. Andrew drifts closer and sees a face, a distended bulk wi tiny eyes. They are alive these hopeless eyes, and they are looking Andrew. We realize this is, was, Colin. His healthy frame mutated into this horrific form. Andrew tries to speak but can’t. He stares terrified. Colin’s eyes jolt with pain; swallowing and breathing at same time. Andrew is close now. Suddenly Colin’s giant arm reaches up. Swollen, gnarled fingers plead for grasp. Andrew looks at the hand and takes it. This monstrous cla somehow tender.

Andrew looks into Colin’s face. It is submitting to some ambient decay, which has weakened the surface so that fla of detritus drift from it. The left side of the head is breaking apart like wet brea The mouth is puffed-up, the lips split, burst like sausag Then, gliding like a car on black ice, Colin’s massive bu is carried away on some current. His eyes longing for rescue remain locked on Andrew until disappears. Andrew is alone again. Held by the black silence and terr We find Colin contained now inside a black box, a helples mound of flesh, elbows, toes, panic, back and bum. The box tips dramatically toward us, pouring him out like child tilted from a basin. He's no longer floating in liquid but carried on it inste round corner after corner by the flush of blackness which swills about his bulk. Then, a settling as the blackness calms. Below him, TWO LONG CYLINDERS are turning inwards on themselves like a mangle, crushing relentlessly. Now this new surface tilts, making him slide in the oily residue that drains off his body. His addled flesh shivers and the flaccid bulk looks like putrefied waste being shed into a bin. The grind and judder of splitting flesh and shattering bo as his legs go in. Stupefaction! His eyes quiver, his lips tremble for some way to squeal but the body is purged of its filling by this abominable machine in less than a breath. The emptying of a life, the discarding of its power, its hunger, its dreams. All sapped away, wrung out. This is a compelling display of destruction. A dark harvesting. An obliteration. An unsettling realization of ignominious, absolute ending  42 43 45. The flow of blood and flesh is quelled through sluices, t away down long trickling gutters into another darkness. The PURGED SKIN is seen now, spewing paper-thin from the mangle. Unrecognizable as human skin. Expelled like an empty disheveled bag, no longer needed. The rollers release their grip and it falls away. Almost weightless, it drifts in the dead airless void lik vast, broken, burst-shaped feather.

Hard, crisp sunlight blasts the front of a sandstone building. This reflected light frames a recessed doorway, which hol no detail, it is a simple black void. We recognise what this darkness signifies. We look into it and, rather than gradually being able to discern some detail, the darkness persists in giving noth away. Then we hear a door latch turn and the heave of a door be pushed wide. We hear the familiar click-click and swish of Laura's sho and dress, and she emerges into the light. We close on her face as she reacts to the glare of hard midday sun. She identifies her path away from the scene of the crime starts walking. We track with her, close on her face the whole time. As she walks into the perfect day, we hear the sounds of world all around her. The birds sing, the wind gathers, traffic hums in the distance, she passes people talking, somewhere nearby som is drilling into the road. Everything is completely ordinary.

Laura is in a long traffic jam approaching a busy junctio On the hunt again.  46. The traffic slips forward at a snail’s pace. The rain ham down. Up ahead, a small, SODDEN MAN carrying plumes of individu wrapped red roses walks on the meridian strip between the traffic. He is trying hard to sell them to the motorists. As she approaches the junction, a curious thing happens. There is a tap on her window. It's another VENDOR, rain streaming down his face. He's waving a rose at her. Her right hand slips down to the little storage panel in door where the bag we saw the gun delivered in sits. Its ragged paper opening is just waiting there. Her fingertips touch the lip of the bag as if checking it availability. The Vendor points over his shoulder. She winds down the window.

(in a foreign voice) The man, he pays you a flower. He points to the traffic which is at a standstill going i the other direction, and to a particular car. A large, plush four wheel drive with a SUITED DRIVER who beams a smile eagerly out across the concrete to her open window.

He saw you, the man saw you. She takes the rose. Easier than not to. Her window drifts against the squall. The Vendor steps away and the traffic shunts on. She tosses the flower on the seat. A tragic ‘toot toot!’ the flash car draws her eye. The idiot in the 4x4 is waving his fingers out a slit he' opened in the window. She returns her focus to the car in front which is just stealing forward another few feet. As she engages the accelerator, she looks at her hand on steering wheel.  44 47. There is a bright, red droplet on the index finger of her right hand. The one she grabbed the rose with. She stops moving forward. She brings the finger up to the space about three inches front of her nose. It's blood! Her blood? That's not possible, she has no blood. Her hand rotates in some weird horror as she searches for prick. She can’t find one. With her other hand she tentatively picks up the single s She examines it - rotating it, careful to avoid any part it that might contain a thorn. And then, there it is - piercing the cellophane sheath li an exotic dagger. She studies it - blood coats the spike and a red droplet two sit among the many rain drops. She looks out the window to the Vendor crossing through t standstill traffic. He’s winding a tissue paper bandage around his hand. Myst solved. She squashes the blood between her thumb and index finger a horn sounds. The space of about a car’s length has opened up in front her and this of course is intolerable for the traffic tha lie directly behind her.

A LONE MAN walks. Laura is watching as she creeps the van along at a snails pace, waiting to seize her moment, but the backstreet she in is too narrow to pull up alongside him. He suddenly turns down an alleyway. Laura pulls up opposi the alley. She slips out of the cab and follows after him.  45 48.

She hurries and takes the corner he did hoping to catch a glimpse of him, or better still that he catches a glimpse her. But he's not to be seen, just the sound of footsteps, fai and fainter. She hurries along after them. She comes to a turning but she can't make out which way t sound is coming from. She chooses straight ahead and, after hard walking for another few seconds, realizes he's not going to be found. She turns back on herself again and, with a sharpness in step, soon finds her way back to the street where she lef the van. But the van is gone. She looks up and down the street as if someone might step and with a shrug admit to the silly practical joke. But n one comes forth. The streets seem narrower than before when she was in the van. The houses are taller on each side of the road. A dog barks somewhere. A light goes on in a window high above her. She walks on. A shadow moves up ahead and A FIGURE walks out of the dar across the street and into a house. On she goes. A sudden racket as loud unwholesome laughter grates again the night breeze. Laura halts and seems for a moment almost about to turn round. She calculates her options before hurrying on. She is scanning everywhere now, watching for the scum and slime that she knows is out there. She's seen it in action, she knows its dark hungers. Noises seem to ooze from all sides. A bottle shatters somewhere round the corner. Distant shouting and doors slamming.  46 47 49. She slides suddenly down a grassy bank and jumps into the ditch at the bottom. She crawls under a door, which has been fly-tipped along a load of filth, and hides. Under there, she stops fretting and maybe even stops breathing. This is the way to lay low. This is the way to survive fo now.

Laura is on the opposite side of the street to the car po She is looking through its gates at the Bad Man saying something to a car pound EMPLOYEE which makes him laugh a hearty, sordid sort of laugh. Soon we see Laura's van approaching. And as the man delivering it gets out, the chit is stampe and the Bad Man shakes the employees hand. The Bad Man then gets into the van and drives it out onto road. He pulls up a short way from the pound and gets out. He hands Laura the keys as she approaches and moves off towards his motorbike without a word. The charming grin and ebullient demeanor he showed to the pound employee is gone without a trace. Laura gets in and drives away.

A distant FIGURE in a trench coat is walking by the side the road, bent over against the rain. The van draws along side him but he doesn't even look at Just moves on. The van persists there at walking pace. Finally he stops. The van stops. His head is still bowed into the rain, then slowly he lif it and half turns to face the van.  48 50.
Laura's driving. The man in the trench-coat sits in the passenger seat half turned towards the window. Rain thund down on the van.

You should get that coat off. He fumbles awkwardly at the sodden coat to remove it. His head is shrouded by the hood of his sweat top. He pushes into the seat so as to obscure himself from Lau vision. His hand comes up to draw the hood back, and as he does s there is a moment... a moment of halting sorrow. The first note of disquiet is to see the paleness of his skin. Alarm heightens as deformed lumps reveal themselves to be lips, eyelids and ears. There is no balance to the congenitally deformed landscap this face. It is a mish-mash of monstrous features collid He leans down to the coat and transfers a glinting DOG WHISTLE from its pocket. He taps the rain out, sucks it dry, then tucks it safe in his shirt pocket. Now he turns in her direction, revealing it all, and she already there, waiting for his eyes to meet hers. And once they do, he sees her face is entirely untroubled his. His mother wouldn't have been able to look at him as she now. When people look at him they feel genetic shame. But she looks at him like he has a normal face.
Do people scream?
What!?
When you come out from under that hood?
Oh.  51. The man sits in the corner of the cab unnerved and uncomfortable. Then Laura looks over at him with a totally carefree smil an irresistible smile, and then back at the road.
Well do they?
Children scream.
Do you get used to it? He shakes his head.

Are you annoyed because I kept you standing in that rain? I just suddenly thought, 'Who am I picking up?' Because of your hood and everything... and then I thought, I can't leave anyone to walk in this. He tries to distract himself from her beauty by looking o of his window.
What's the matter?
Nothing.
Do you mind me mentioning it?
Mentioning what?
You know..you're face. It's obvious his thoughts are jumbled. His eyes look to t floor. He tries to get his feelings out but they’re confused.
Have I upset you?
No. I don't care. Well, no If you want to know... I just don't need it.  52.
Sorry I just thought it's better to be straight. She gives the impression of someone trying to think of something to say.
Do you go in to Doach often then?
Every few days.
Have you got friends there?
I go in to find work, once or twice a month. Down near the docks, they come along and pick you out the line.
What sort of work?
Cleaning, laboring. Cash in hand. I got a night watchman job once but I couldn't hold on to it because of George.
(delicately focusing on the new information) Who's George? You didn't mention George.
My dog.
Your doggy, Oh! Who's looking after him tonight?
He can look after himself.
Where is he?
He'll be under the willows. Waiting for me.
What willows?  53.
I have a wee camp in Grancha Park.
Is that the one with the big wall round it? That's about five miles back.
Yeah.
Why couldn't you keep that job then?
Well he's alright if I'm gone for a night but if it's too regular or more than a night he goes loony, howling and barking... someone's been murdered when they hear him.
He misses you.
Aye.
So why are you traveling at this time of night?
Because it takes a couple of hours to walk there.
You’re quite a tough little man aren't you! She gives a longer more overtly admiring look.
(bemused) What's going on? (to himself) What's happening? He finds his mouth working again almost without warning. all suddenly too much for him.
What's happening? Is it a joke or something?
What are you talking about?  54.
You looking at me like you want it. Like it's on a plate.
I'm being nice to you that's all. The little man is almost trembling with nervousness. So f out of his comfort zone.
Why?
Well... I don't know. I like you.
I don't want pity.
And you have a nice mouth... a kind mouth.
My mouth!?
Yes, it's cute! Some people have nice eyes or hair..or big muscles. You have a nice mouth. What's wrong with that? The little man sits with all this revelation churning aro in his little head.
I've got a nice mouth??
Yeah... She looks at him from time to time glancing away from the road, gradually making him more and more comfortable with her warm smiles and that specific kind of eye-contact.

Everybody's got something. I have really nice legs..they're my best part. The Ugly Man's little eyes look down at those long legs. We can see him afraid to look at this kind of woman in th context. She is opening doors he nailed shut a long time ago.  55.
What do you think?
What?
About me? What's my best feature? He looks at her.
Don’t be afraid.
I don't know. Everything?

Oh, that's very nice... I think that's the best compliment I've ever had. They drive now, the rain hammering against the window and Laura smiling so he can see her smile. The Ugly Man is trembling with an intense, alarming excitement. More and more his eyes wander to her, each time she meets gaze with effortless sincerity.
I've got an idea, why don't you come and work for me today instead?
Doing what?
Odd jobs. Nothing too difficult. A few rooms that need sorting out.
How far away is it?
An hour's drive from here.
That's too far, I won't get back in time.

Don't worry about George. I'll drive you back, how's that? I'd like to meet George and see your camp.  49 50 56. We see his hands move furtively as he takes a nip of skin between his thumb and finger... and pinches himself to ma sure he's not dreaming. He looks back at her almost expecting her to disappear.
I can't understand how a bird like you doesn't have a man about. I feel strange.. I don't know what you want me to do.
Oh, don't be nervous. I won't bite.
(suspiciously) I mean what are you doing up here all alone? Driving around all alone?
(smiles) I get asked that question a lot.
Do you ever answer it? She laughs and gives him a little nudge. He smiles, maybe for the first time in years, and in that moment we know he is lost.

A remote derelict house set some way back from the main r Laura is walking toward the door, her key aimed at the lo Behind her the Ugly Man edging along the path with uncert footsteps. The key turns and the interior beckons.

At the end of the hall a staircase winds its way up into infinite blackness. Bits of the ceiling are on the floor and the ancient wallpaper is peeling off the walls. Laura coaxes him in with a smile and swings the door shut behind him. They climb the stairs.  51 57.

As before, the blackness is everywhere. The sounds of the footsteps echo on the black marble floor. As Laura walks, she looks over her shoulder as she lets h top drop through her fingers. The Ugly Man moves as if on a chain. Eyes locked on her. He pulls his shirt up over his torso. The steel dog-whistle pops out of his pocket and falls through the darkness like a slither of sunlight. It lands with a sharp tinkle-tinkle. The noise brings on a silence like that after a gun crack Stirred, he looks at her, the other-worldliness is gone. spell is broken. He opens his mouth weakly.
Ha... Cha Hel Hello...
Hello.
This is... I am. This is... I am asleep?
Yes.
You're asleep too?
Yes I am.
This is great isn't it... I love this.
Yes.
Cold.
We won't let that stop us.
I feel cold? I'm asleep aren't I?  58.

Of course you are. Suddenly afraid, his eyes come off her and he turns the o way. His eyes search the darkness. They don't need to search f There, frozen in different moments of creeping stalk, are FOUR BLACK ALIENS. At first they're just shapes, dream images, unthreatening Yet in a moment, as the idea of them becomes clearer, the become totally menacing. He steps backwards, away from them and towards Laura.
I don't like it... Suddenly she is there on his shoulder.
Where’s George?
Under the willows.
My mouth’s dry. Everything’s going at a hundred miles an hour.

Come to me. The Ugly Man is frozen in some weird mind space. His eyes take in the horror of the place around him and t information freezes him dead so that he can turn neither right or left. His eyes simply dart about trying to find a place to rest that is not crazy and not inhuman and they find her. He steps forward in the direction of that only thing that any hope in it.
I'm dreaming... dreaming.
Yes, yes we are.

Good.  59. As the man takes another step to her, she reaches out to while taking a step backwards and he, like a dumb animal, summoned forward again. Another shape emerges from the darkness... the Bad Man. He steps over to where the little silver dog-whistle fell He crouches now and picks it up carefully. He looks at the object for a moment, then, having underst it, slips it into his pocket. He steps silently back into the depths of the darkness ag and it is as if he had never been there.
You don't want to wake up do you?
No, never.
They're gone.
They better be. Gave me-self a right fright there. (reproaching himself) Fucking shitter.
Come closer. It's warmer here. The Ugly Man comes on reluctantly, like a man stepping on the gallows. He tries a smile, coaxing himself.

(reassuring himself) Okay. Laura is working to keep him in line. He steps on and loo to the floor as it takes him in. He double takes. Laura beckons. He breathes hard, eyes questioning. His limbs edge into action. The shadow figures withdraw. At each step he persuades himself to take the next. The frailty of his progress compels her. Her body falls i a new rhythm, more insistent. Her gyrations become a sensual dance.  52 60. Her fingers click-click to provoke him. His eyes widen. Her arms, hips and neck scintillate. His mouth hangs open. Soon he is in it up to his chin. He takes a long, terrified look at Laura. She smiles at h like nothing's happening. He takes a deep, terrified breath, holds his nose and put his head under. Laura stops, turns and moves back out of the blackness towards the stairs, collecting her clothes as she goes. We read the echo of fragility in the movement of her eyes body. She seems less exact, less vigorous, less disconnected.

Movement through darkness as Laura emerges back into the grey gloom of the house. She is dressing as she walks, unfolding her shirt out fro under her arm and reaching into it. She is on the stairs now as she buttons up, descending quickly to the entrance hall. At the bottom of the stairs she stops to fasten her shoes And as she stands again to approach the front door, she catches sight of something looming next to the door, a sh completely shocking to her. Her own reflection. Still and wary in a large jaded mirror. She is completely startled by it. Alarmed by herself, she backs away. Eyes still locked on her image, which diminishes in size she retreats from it. She stands stock still and looks away. Then the slowest head turn ever back to the mirror until locks eyes with herself. Then she approaches her reflection with trepidation.  53 61. Now she's close up to it. The eyes lock, reflection and reflectee. Mesmerized. She raises her hand to touch her reflected hand. A standing chill. She looks at her face from different angles. Slowly and deliberately shifting her pose, like an animal coming to terms with its own existence. Like light comprehending glass.

The Bad Man steps off his motorbike and moves to the wrou iron gates of Grancha Parkland. They are locked. He steps back, scanning the area. He throws his leg over metal spikes. He walks up the pasture. Three weeping willows rustle in wind. He gets to about twenty feet away and stops.
(calls) George!... George! Nothing. He looks about. Moves closer to the hulking tree Listening. The trees groan in the wind.

George. Suddenly there is a scramble in the leaves near him. He turns to face the sound. The wind whistles. Then aggressive barking... but in the other direction. He turns. Suddenly he reaches for his leg and spins. His hands tear whatever is grasping his thigh. In the half light he can A MASSIVE ALSATIAN. George. Eyes rolling in anger, teeth locked into his leg. George twists trying to tear the leg off. He raises a fist but as he brings it down, the beast is g  54 62. The Bad man moves towards a fallen tree and gathers up a stick. Armed, he turns, but at that moment, George is in the air leaping at his throat. The man gets his arm up. George knocks him to the ground and is on him, teeth lock on his forearm. H He reaches to tear it away. George snaps viciously at the hand, then bounds off. The Bad Man gets unsteadily to his feet. The beast is moving at the edge of the willows. The Bad M looks at it. It looks at him. The Bad Man turns seeking higher ground or some other advantage. George bounds out into the clearing. Then checks and retu into cover. The Bad Man is struggling to keep the animal in his sight The trees hiss and groan in the winds. The Bad Man suddenly turns to and strides for the gate. H clambers over it. We see George weave amidst the trees. There, ominous for a moment, then gone. The Bad Man clutches at his forearm, trying to stem a hig pitch wheeze of escaping gas from the wound. An insistent hiss like decompression is visible through t flapping edges of the ripped sleeve. He takes A GUN from his inside pocket and loads the clip. He reaches into his pocket. Takes out the Ugly Man's dog- whistle, holds it to his lips and blows. We hear nothing.

Laura is still looking at herself in the mirror. From somewhere nearby, a strange buzzing seeps into the space. It drones and persists, becoming frantic. The space falls silent for a brief moment then the buzz starts up again. Relentless and adamant.  55 63. The noise is such that we see Laura slip out from her confrontation with her own reflection. She turns and there in a little window above the mirror i the source of the noise. A BEE throwing itself in skittish pulses at the glass desperate to escape to the brightening dawn light outside Laura's eyes, weary and bewildered, just watch it. Its wings beat against the glass, the sound intensifying until it seems the insect might almost burst into flame s is its desire. And in that moment we can see that something within Laura slain and something born. Slowly, she reaches towards it. Her hand moves along the glass then scoops it up lightly without haste, closes her fingers around it. The bee is inside her fist now and the buzzing is wild. We focus on Laura's hand as she walks slowly through the hall. We hear the sound of the desperate insect thrashing again her closed palm. She reaches the door and her other hand twists the handle open.

We cut outside to see her fist open and the bee fly out f it. She draws the door shut again without haste and we remain with the bee as it weaves lazily towards the ragged flowe in this forgotten garden. We watch it arrive at a blossom and alight on it. It steps over the bright yellow petals to gently find its to the pollen rich core inside. The buzzing is different now - soothing, and the skittish replaced with a swaying, humming dance. The bee is blushed with pollen as it emerges like some dr lover crawling out of an orgy. It rises into the air again, drifting with the wind to it next beautiful rendezvous.  56 64. We hear a metallic rasp. The front door is being pushed open again. TWO FIGURES, just silhouettes in the gloom of the interio first stumble out of the house. They seem to shy from the light for a moment but it is si balance they are struggling with. Laura and something heaving for breath. They're holding each other. They draw closer. She is holding it up. Supporting it, walking it. It's standing now, sucking in air through its tiny missha mouth. It has legs, massive, bloated, and arms that hang flaccid Yet somewhere inside this bulbous mass, the folds of fat, taut skin about to burst.. is a man. The Ugly Man. They glint now as they step out of the building’s shadow. they're wet. Laura's hair trails over the Ugly Man as she struggles, holding him. Sodden and weak they move slowly. They step uneasily with each other. He manages to hold onto a tree, but now he straightens, s to find his feet. She lets him step... then step again. He's walking, she moves away from him, willing him to kee moving. He steadies himself, then presses on. She hurries to the van and starts it urgently. The gears grind as it roars out of the drive.
Laura is driving hard away from the house. Fleeing. We see her over-take the struggling figure of the Ugly Ma and out onto an A road.  57 58 65.

A small, suburban cul-de-sac on the very edge of a field. The Ugly Man is crawling, dragging himself through the mu ground towards it. His bloated bulk is sweating and breathless from the effo his flesh torn and bruised from his journey. The rooftops of the houses loom above the hedges, he seem feet away from rescue, as if he could almost reach out fo doorbell and everything would be alright. The Bad Man enters the scene with sudden, alarming resolv His bike revs at the entrance to the field. He looks into intensely and sees the long grass move from something crawling through it. He shifts the bike into gear and we see him make a b-line the cul-de-sac.

Birds are flitting in a bird table. The PAPER BOY is cycl down the hill to the shops. Steam is coming from the vent outside bathroom windows. The small close is waking up. The Bad Man pulls up at the mouth of the street, stops th bike and dismounts. He can see the bulk of the Ugly Man just appearing throug the ragged hedges that scrub onto the pavement. Facing him are the garden gates and beyond the waking hou and certain rescue. The Bad Man is now running. He heads for a car parked in driveway. He arrives at the drivers window and ploughs hi fist through it. He reaches inside and opens the door with deft continuous movement and gets in. A moment later the engine starts and the car is eased int reverse, suddenly everything is controlled urgency again. He turns and takes off. He stops just ahead of the Ugly Man who is now half on th path, gets out, opens the back door then walks over to hi and drags him back towards the car, glancing about at win and doors with the full awareness that they might open at moment. The Ugly Man is bundled in head first.  59 60 66.
(muffled)

The Bad Man unleashes vicious blows to his mouth and temp then hurries around the car, opens the other back door, l in and drags him inside by the armpits. The Bad Man now walks back to the opposite side, folds an errant leg in then slams the door shut. Then he gets in.

The handbrake is released, the wheels turn, dust and flec rise in the air. A net curtain is swept wide to see the car drive casually away and out of the street. We are close on the Bad Man's face. We/he hears the sound of a woman's shocked voice, intimat as if she was in the car with us. WOMAN’S VOICE Oh my God... The Bad Man turns his head very suddenly and looks out of passenger window, crouching to see the upper floor of one the little houses. He looks directly to where the voice is coming from. There standing at the bedroom window is an OLD WOMAN. She is looking straight at the Bad Man as he drives out o the street. As he slows, she lets the curtain close. And through the nets he sees her silhouette as she shakil raises a phone to her ear. He almost stops but instead guns the engine into life and advances in a cloud of exhaust fumes.

Laura storms through the countryside. Green flashes on either side, the road is a gleaming slat cord that stretches out away from her, drawing her in and along.  67. Then without warning everything slows. The engine dies, the steering stiffens. She looks at her dials. The petrol gauge tells its tale. for the end. She brings the van onto the verge by a lake and lets it r to a standstill. Puts on the hand brake and gets out. Without missing a be she sets off at a march. The camera sweeps fast along the road - it is travelling fifteen feet above the tarmac. We soar over a blind summit and there just on the bend is Laura's van. It's empty. We slow to see inside, no sign of life, other than her gu and phone buzzing on the passenger seat. We resume our plunge through the landscape. Faster and faster. Another two miles down the road and we see a figure up ah walking fast along the highway. It's Laura. She slows as if sensing that there is something pursuing Soon we are right behind her. We can almost see the hairs the back of her neck rising. She turns suddenly as if ready to confront whatever or whoever is there. But there is nothing there. Just her standing on the road, alone, in the middle of nowhere. We see trembling fear freeze in her face, uncertainty in eyes. Doubt, suspicion, the expectation of doom is locked in he gaze as it searches out to the horizon for the thing that must come. But it doesn't. She looks at this wild world around her. The bleak moors, the mountains beyond. And the sounds of the wind rushing through this valley se to harmonize in some rhapsody as if finding clarity withi her hearing for the first time.  61 68. We can see that somehow, in facing her fear, she has foun something else instead. A strange sense of acceptance. She stands letting these feelings take root. The wind blusters through her hair and clothes, and we wa as she lifts and stretches her arms and fingers wide and to feel it. And standing still, it's as if the world falls into her. She closes those beautiful eyes with abandon as if she fe the sensual possibilities of this body for the first time The wind embraces her.

We are in a tiny roadside cafe with views out over hills heather. The place is busy with tourists, back packs at their feet sipping tea and munching scones. Laura sits on her own at a little tartan-covered table. There is a plate in front of her and on it, a piece of ca She regards it with trepidation. It's a beautiful object, sculptural and garish. White and fluffy, with cream falling from its centre and a varnishe cherry on top. She lifts her fork and cuts into it delicately. Up and up it comes, the distance between the plate and he mouth seems extraordinarily long. It arrives at her lips, which open tentatively as she slo eases the magical parcel of nectar inside. Then she lowers the fork back to the plate. Now she sits as if her every thought was with this intrud inside her. Her mouth is still as she contemplates her next move. Suddenly her jaw moves and she begins to chew. But so cautiously, like she were defusing a bomb. A moment later she is still again. She decides to swallow And then shock, at not being able to. She coughs into her hand violently. Laura fumbles for a napkin to catch the mouthful of food and wipes her mouth.  62 63 69. Heads have turned to see what the commotion is. Through faint breath, Laura waves the attention away as i say ‘I'm fine.’
(recomposing) It just went down the wrong way.

location: COUNTRY INN. HIGHLANDS. SHORT WHILE LATER. 62

text: Cut to a roaring fire. A pair of hands enter frame and wa themselves at the glow. Cut wide to see Laura in front of a large open fire ina pleasant country inn. There is an atmosphere of convivial early evening chat an sheltering welcome. She warms herself and listens to the sounds of humanity c its soothing tones in the warmth.

Laura is walking - walking - walking. She is approaching a junction where A MAN waits at a bus stop. He notices her coming, her long legs striding, her shoes made for walking clattering. We see him avert his gaze like a gentleman as she draws n He's a drawn pale being, full of thoughts. She marches past without noticing or slowing. When she's about fifteen feet beyond the stop, he turns a calls after her.

The bus'll be along in a minute. Laura looks round surprised by the outburst. She looks at him blankly for a moment. He looks away with a demeanor that says 'well that's the information, do with it as you will’. Laura considers for a beat longer, then makes her way bac towards the bus stop.  64 70.

location: BUS. ROAD TO CAWDOR. SHORT WHILE LATER. 64

text: Laura and the Quiet Man on an empty bus. Laura is sitting right behind the driver staring straight into that black panel that separates him from the passeng The Quiet Man sits a little further back. He is looking at her, or rather at her face reflected in dark panel. He can tell she is not absentmindedly staring into mid sp but unflinchingly at her own reflection. He feels his breath stop as that face stares at itself, completely absorbed, suspicious and lost.
Have you no jacket with you? Nothing from Laura.

Up here you need a jacket with you - even when there's not a cloud in the sky, rain's always a possibility. Laura looks out the window now. We see her soften into th hum of the bus as it climbs. The mountains closing in aro them. The Quiet Man notices Laura's open purse on the seat besi her. Her change is slipping out of it, along the worn fabric a onto the floor with every change of gear. She seems obliv to it. The Quiet Man steps across the aisle, gathers the coins without any fuss then lets them stream through his finger into the purse. He snaps it shut. It's all done in a moment and he places the purse beside as he turns away. As he sits, Laura speaks.
Where am I?
On the road to Cawdor.
Is it a busy place?  71.
No, it’s a quiet place. (Beat) Is that where you're headed?
No.
Where are you headed?
I don't know.
Are you okay? Has something happened?
Yes, I’m alright. I think. Where would you go?
How's that?
If you could go anywhere... where would you go?
Sight seeing do you mean?
Yes, that’s it. Sight seeing. The beautiful landscape rolls by outside the rain swept window and we see this man begin to think.
Well there are a million places. That’s no use to her, so she leans slightly forward and repeats the question for the driver, seeking a serious answer.

If you could go anywhere... where would you go? We glimpse her desperation. As the driver ponders, we see the Quiet Man looking at th back of Laura's head. She's unaware of him now, every fibre of her being listen for an answer from the lump at the wheel.  65 66 67 72.
I’d start with Cawdor Castle. She ignores that answer, so as to conceal its importance her.

(to driver with a casual but precise tone) Then I'd like to go to Cawdor Castle please. She returns to staring into the weird black space that ho in front of her in which everything seems to shudder and sway, everything except her.

The bus is pulling away from the town bus stop. The Quiet Man and Laura are walking up the high street. L has his big coat draped over her shoulders. They could as easily be with each other as not. The dista between them is the distance maintained by strangers and holds it.

We are in a vast, white supermarket. Laura shadows the Quiet Man as he navigates his trolley through the aisles. He considers a pre-packed casserole, checking the price t before replacing it. Laura's face, almost cocooned in his big heavy coat, is bleached out under the glare of the kilowatts, which blas everything with a cleansing intensity.

location: ROAD TO THE QUIET MAN'S HOUSE. SHORT WHILE LATER. 67

text: Two figures walking. The Quiet Man carries plastic bags. Laura follows in his strides. He trudges up the little path to the door of a concrete council house and finds the keyhole. She follows him inside without ceremony.  68 73.

location: THE QUIET MAN'S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. SHORT WHILE LATE

text: A little room bathed in half-light from the dense curtain Laura sits on a low, brown couch under the window; the Qu Man in an armchair. They are watching a show on television together, dinner o their laps. Laura leans over her food, her hand moves here and there, selecting but unsure. The Quiet Man wipes his plate clean with a piece of bread Laura brings a forkful of meat up to her mouth and insert like a child who has just mastered the art of cutlery. Her lips close tight around the delivery. She tries to swallow. Same result as when she tried to eat the cake, sudden ten gripping her face and throat. She sets the fork aside with a rattle and brings her hand her mouth to suppress a violent choke. The Quiet Man is on his feet and reaching his big hand ar to pat her back. She gets up and shuffles towards what must be the bathroo We see the Quiet Man return to his seat and sit listening The sounds coming up the hall seem controlled. He sips fr large mug. His eyes return to the television.

A record revolves on a plastic turntable. We see the Quiet Man on his knees slipping a black disc b into its paper sleeve then stand and return to his armcha Music fills the room. 'Wild is The Wind' by David Bowie. Laura sits back into the sofa, her eyes gazing into the ceiling. The music builds and the space slips incrementally into a different attitude. We follow Laura's eyes around the room. To see the old framed photos and ephemera accumulated by ordinary life.  69 74. Then to the television still on - alive with the image of tiger prowling through long grass. Her gaze comes to rest on the Quiet Man, his eyes shut, h hand pats the arm of his chair gently in time with the mu He looks happy and tired. Laura joins the moment by mimicking his, her hand now als tap tap-taping on the arm of her chair in time with the rhythm. He stirs, looks at her for a moment and there is nothing strange to be seen, everything is completely normal, Laur listening to the music with him. Without a word he stands, picks up the tray and leaves th room. The moment he’s out of the room, Laura's hand stops movin We watch Laura now so still and void with the music swirl around her and we feel the vast distance between her and humanity. We hear the sounds of the kitchen things being put away a tap running. Laura remains still. The music builds the energy in it stepping relentlessly to crescendo. Laura now looks down at her hand in that disassociated wa she does. She seems somehow to be trying to find a connection to th action. Her fingers tap in and around the beat rather than on it now... She is no longer mimicking... There is something happening there at the extremity of her craft... somethin seeping in. She looks down at the moving limb as if it’s a curiosity her.

location: THE QUIET MAN'S HOUSE. BEDROOM. SHORT WHILE LATER. 6

text: Laura lies in the Quiet Man's bed. Her eyes are set in so mid-point. The Quiet Man sets a dainty cup of tea and saucer on a cardboard box near the bed as if it were the finest delic Laura's eyes read it, then seem to return to the ceiling a kind of meditative state.
(sense-checking) You don’t feel with your brain.  70 75.

No you don't. He angles a bar fire towards her with the toe of his boot then takes his leave. We slowly drift from Laura's face to the open door, which leads to the front room. The Quiet Man is sitting back in his armchair. He puts a leg up on a stool in a vain attempt to find comfort. His head slumps slowly to the side as he falls asleep in chair like a kind of giant guarding a princess. Slowly the ambience of safety overrides the small house. Nothing moves.

Undulating hills reaching trees and peaty bog. She is guided by him - led up rocky paths and down slippe banks. They reach a fast flowing stream with stepping-stones dot across its width. A little waterfall a hundred yards away roars. Trees rust in accord and the sky seems open to the attendant energie She looks down at the water, judging it, and he in that s moment instinctively without a word gathers her up into h arms. She does not waver as he steps out onto the semi-submerge stones. He finds his balance and moves with that focused certaint that a man finds when he's in charge of something he care about. She is motionless in his arms. He senses her trust and is emboldened by it. They are almost over to the other side. He stops to look along the river and nods to her to look too. She follows his gesture and can see figures, edging towar the ledge of the waterfall. Screams of exhilaration as a figure rushes over the ledge plunges.  71 76. Another figure throws itself into space, giving itself ov to the affects of gravity and water. Laughter explodes with splashes as more bodies launch int space.
